abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Mizoram State Roads
            Project for India were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            inclusion of too many components in a project (six in this
            case) negatively affects implementation, because both the
            client and the Bank have limited resources for effective
            supervision and implementation. When clients have limited
            capacity to begin with, it may be prudent to limit
            components to fewer with a similar implementation format.
            Similarly, the project should not have too many indicators.
            Fewer, measurable and objective monitoring indicators and a
            well designed evaluation system will better assess the
            baselines and subsequently achievement of project outcomes.
            Special measures should also be introduced to ensure top
            caliber consultants are appointed when local capacity is
            weak. In this case inferior consultants paid on a time basis
            were in effect rewarded because of the project delays. The
            project should have adequate contingency arrangements in
            line with Bank norms. Bio-engineering measures using local
            bamboo and traditional techniques may be used to stabilize
            landslide-prone hill sides. This promotes local employment
            generation. The success of using such techniques in this
            project has led to replication in areas such as Himachal
            Pradesh. Debris disposed in an environmentally friendly
            manner can also benefit the community. In the Mizoram
            project the debris provided a unique opportunity to create
            football pitches and water storage ponds for the local community.

India - Mizoram State Roads Project :
            additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's development objective
            is to improve the management and carrying capacity of the
            Mizoram core state road network. The project comprises six
            components: (a) improvement (widening and strengthening) of
            about 184 km State Highways; b) implementation o f the
            Resettlement and Indigenous People Development Plan
            (R&IPDP), Environmental Management Plan (EMP), and land
            acquisition and utility relocation plan associated with road
            improvement component; c) rehabilitation and maintenance of
            about 520 km of state roads; d) design, supervision and
            technical advisory services for civil works; e)
            institutional strengthening, including equipment, TA,
            training, and pre-investment studies; and f) road safety
            engineering interventions.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Mizoram State Road and Rural
            Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Mizoram State Road and Rural Development Project for
            India, which supports the major improvement of capacity as
            well as structural upgrading of the road network in the
            state of Mizoram. The negative environmental impacts will be
            mitigated in the following ways: Massive hill cutting
            affecting the stability of slopes is a key issue. Other
            concerns relate to the damage to the road formation, damage
            to the hillside flora and fauna, and disruption to traffic.
            Based on the geological setting, zoning has been worked out
            and cut slopes recommended. Locations vulnerable to
            landslides have been identified, and at most locations,
            mitigation measures as rock bolting, provision of band
            drains where required, and bio-engineering techniques that
            stabilize vertically cut slopes adopted. To prevent loss of
            biodiversity, physical damage or removal of individual
            plants close to the existing carriageway and on the hillside
            where cutting will occur during construction will be
            minimized. Pipe culverts and barbed wire fencing will
            prevent ecological disturbance. Other mitigations include
            identifying disposal areas for construction debris,
            locations for water harvesting and storage, and traffic
            diversion and timing of activities. Other measures address
            involuntary resettlement, indigenous populations, and income
            restoration. Further volumes focus on major maintenance
            routes, environmental impact assessment, and sectoral
            environmental assessment.
